text: Gore-Booth in 1968 Paul Henry Gore-Booth, Baron Gore-Booth (3 February 1909 – 29 June 1984) was a British diplomat. He served with distinction in HM Diplomatic Service and in retirement held the following appointments: Director, Grindlays Bank, 1969–79, United Kingdom Provident Institution, 1969–79 and Registrar, Order of St Michael and St George, 1966–79.www.npg.org.uk Lord Gore-Booth was educated at Eton and Balliol. After Oxford, he married in 1940, Patricia Mary Ellerton, by whom he had twin sons one of whom was Sir David Gore-Booth and two daughters. His aunt was the Irish republican and socialist revolutionary, Countess Constance Markievicz (née Gore-Booth).www.thepeerage.com ==Career== Gore-Booth joined the British Foreign Service in 1933, serving in the Foreign Office in London from 1933–36, and then was stationed in Vienna, 1936–37, Tokyo, 1938–42, and Washington, 1942–45, where he attended the Hot Springs Food Conference in 1943. He returned to the Foreign Office in London, 1945–49, attending the UNRRA Conference, 1943, the Chicago Civil Aviation Conference, 1944, the San Francisco Conference, 1945, and the UN Assembly, January and October 1946 (as Secretary of the UK Delegation), and in 1947 as the British Representative, Group of Four Drafting Convention setting up the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development. He served as Head of the UN Economic and Social and Refugees Departments, 1947–48; Head of European Recovery Department, Foreign Office, 1948–49; Director of British Information Services in United States, 1949–53; Ambassador to Burma, 1953–56; Deputy Under-Secretary (Economic Affairs), Foreign Office, 1956–60; British High Commissioner in India, 1960–65; Permanent Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, 1965–69; and Head of HM Diplomatic Service, 1968–69. Gore-Booth also served as President of the Sherlock Holmes Society of London, 1967–79; Chairman, Save the Children Fund, 1970–76; Chairman, Windsor Music Festival, 1971–73; Member, Disasters Emergency Committee, 1974–77; Chairman, Board of Governors, School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, 1975–80. ==Honours and arms== *45px CMG (1949), KCMG (1957), GCMG (1965); *45px KCVO (1961); *Life Peer as Baron Gore-Booth, of Maltby in the West Riding of the County of York (cr. 2 July 1969). ==Works== * With Great Truth and Respect (autobiog.) 1974 * Satow's Guide to Diplomatic Practice, 5th edn, 1978. ==See also== * Gore baronets * Booth baronets ==References== ==External links== * www.burkespeerage.com Category:1909 births Category:1984 deaths Category:People educated at Eton College Category:Alumni of Balliol College, Oxford Category:Crossbench life peers Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George Category:Knights Commander of the Royal Victorian Order Category:Ambassadors of the United Kingdom to Myanmar Category:High Commissioners of the United Kingdom to India Category:Permanent Under-Secretaries of State for Foreign Affairs Category:Members of HM Diplomatic Service Paul
